current_state_2026.global_defense_spending: $2.72T (+9.4% YoY real, highest since Cold War)
current_state_2026.defense_industrial_base_companies: 100,000+ firms in DIB, 73% are small businesses
current_state_2026.ai_adoption_level: early_to_growing — Maven at scale, PANDA fielded, but most units still manual

key_programs.project_maven: Palantir MSS contract raised to $1.3B ceiling through 2029. By June 2026 Maven will transmit 100% machine-generated intelligence to combatant commanders.
key_programs.replicator_1: Fielded hundreds (not thousands) of ADA2 systems by Aug 2025. Below target but still largest autonomous weapons fielding in history.
key_programs.replicator_2: Counter-sUAS focus. First acquisition announced Jan 2026 (Fortem DroneHunter F700).
key_programs.jadc2: Enterprise C2 program office standing up. Maven provides cloud/AI backbone for CJADC2.
key_programs.synthetic_training_env: VR/AR/AI training systems procured FY2025, fielding to CTC sites starting FY2026.
key_programs.panda: USAF predictive maintenance suite — identifies at-risk components before failure.
key_programs.cmmc_2_0: Formally embedded in DFARS contracts. 220K+ DIB companies must certify. 15-20% expected to exit.

what_changes: Manual intelligence analysis -> AI-generated intelligence at scale (Maven 100% machine-generated by mid-2026)
Manned platforms -> autonomous/unmanned systems (DoD buying 200,000 UAS in 2027 alone)
Reactive maintenance -> AI predictive maintenance (Army uptime 85% -> 95%)
Traditional force training -> synthetic AI-generated training environments
Legacy supply chain -> AI-optimized defense logistics
Human-only decision loops -> human-machine teaming at tactical edge

timeline.2026: CMMC enforcement begins in contracts. Maven 100% machine-generated intel. Replicator 2 first fieldings. STE at first CTC site.
timeline.2027: DoD buys 200K UAS. JADC2 enterprise C2 office operational. Arsenal-1 (Anduril) production begins.
timeline.2028_2030: NATO 5% GDP ramp steepens. European defense AI spending doubles. Counter-UAS market 5x from today.
timeline.2030_2035: Full autonomous swarm operations. AI-native defense logistics. Nuclear-powered autonomous undersea vehicles.

second_order_effects: CMMC enforcement drives 15-20% DIB contraction -> surviving firms gain pricing power
Autonomous systems require new supply chains -> defense manufacturing reshoring accelerates
AI predictive maintenance reduces $5B/yr DoD costs -> freed budget flows to new programs
European rearmament creates export market for US defense AI startups
Defense AI talent pipeline creates spillover to commercial AI applications

economic_force_quantification.ai_cost_compression_target: 15-30% of defense operations are routine-cognitive and compressible
economic_force_quantification.jevons_expansion: At lower unit costs for autonomous systems, demand expands 3-10x (see: Ukraine drone consumption rates vs. pre-war projections)
economic_force_quantification.key_insight: Defense is the ONE sector where the buyer (government) has unlimited budget authority and demonstrated willingness to pay premium for speed. Normal market dynamics don't apply — cost savings are secondary to capability delivery.

fear_friction_profile.notes: Defense buyers are EAGER for AI. Fear friction runs in the opposite direction from civilian sectors — the fear is of NOT adopting AI fast enough while adversaries do. CMMC/compliance is the primary friction point, not AI adoption resistance.

existing_coverage: V3-DEF-001: Autonomous Drone Swarm Command Platform (82.0) — STRUCTURAL_WINNER
V3-DEF-002: Defense AI/ML Intelligence Fusion Platform (81.25) — FORCE_RIDER
V3-DEF-003: Cybersecurity AI for Defense Networks (81.75) — STRUCTURAL_WINNER
V3-DEF-004: Defense Logistics AI Optimizer (77.5) — FORCE_RIDER
V3-DEF-005: European Defense-Tech AI Platform (73.25) — FORCE_RIDER
V3-DEF-006: Dual-Use Autonomous Vehicle Platform (73.25) — CONDITIONAL
V3-DEF-007: Satellite/Space ISR AI Analytics (77.0) — FORCE_RIDER
V3-DEF-008: Defense Supply Chain Reshoring Enabler (74.5) — FORCE_RIDER
V3-DEF-009: Autonomous Undersea Systems AI — CONDITIONAL
V3-DEF-010: Defense Predictive Maintenance AI (78.0) — FORCE_RIDER
gaps_identified: NO CMMC/compliance automation model — 220K+ companies MUST certify, 73% are small businesses, most paying $75K-$150K
NO defense AI deployment infrastructure model — IL5/IL6 classified environment tooling is a massive gap
NO counter-UAS/counter-drone specific model — $2.6B market growing at 25.8% CAGR, Replicator 2 creating demand
NO defense workforce training simulation model — $13.4B market, STE fielding in 2026
NO defense AI proposal/contract capture model — $49.1B in defense tech VC, every startup needs to navigate SBIR/IDIQ/OTA
NO defense-specific AI testing/evaluation model — DoD needs to verify AI systems before deployment
NO DIB supply chain compliance/visibility model — defense supply chain is unique regulatory environment

model_cards.model_name: CMMC Compliance Automation Platform for Defense Contractors
model_cards.one_line: AI platform automating CMMC Level 1-3 compliance for 220K+ DIB companies, replacing $75-150K manual assessments
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + CMMC 2.0 enforcement in DFARS contracts (2026)

demand_drivers: CMMC 2.0 formally embedded in DFARS — every DoD contractor MUST certify starting 2026
220,000+ companies in Defense Industrial Base need compliance
73% of DIB firms are small businesses paying $75K-$150K for manual compliance
Only 60+ authorized C3PAOs exist — massive bottleneck for 220K companies needing assessment
15-20% of DIB companies expected to exit due to compliance cost burden
FY2026 NDAA mandates AI-specific cybersecurity framework within CMMC
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: 220K companies need CMMC certification but only 60+ C3PAOs exist. Manual compliance costs $75K-$150K per firm. Small defense contractors (73% of DIB) cannot afford consultants. AI-automated compliance reduces cost to $5K-$25K while accelerating timeline from 6-12 months to 2-4 months.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: CMMC is now in DFARS. Contractors lose contracts without certification. The math is simple: 220K companies, 60 assessors, 6-12 month process = decade-long queue without automation. AI compliance platforms are structurally necessary to prevent DIB collapse.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: LLMs can parse NIST 800-171 controls, map organizational practices to compliance requirements, generate POAMs, and maintain continuous monitoring. AI reduces a 6-12 month manual compliance process to 2-4 months with 70% less consultant time.

CMMC exists because of adversary cyber threats to the DIB. Every major defense breach (OPM, F-35 data, CUI exfiltration) strengthened the mandate. Geopolitical competition ensures CMMC enforcement only tightens, never relaxes.

Defense tech VC hit $49.1B in 2025. Compliance-enabling platforms are lower risk than hardware plays. PE-backed defense services firms need compliance solutions to maintain contract eligibility during refinancing pressure.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Software-only, no hardware dependencies. Requires access to NIST frameworks (public) and CMMC assessment guides (public).

regulatory_contagion.notes: CMMC 2.0 enforcement is the DRIVER of this model. Regulatory expansion (AI-specific security framework in FY2026 NDAA) expands TAM. Zero risk of deregulation — bipartisan defense cybersecurity support.

competitive_import.notes: Existing players: Secureframe, Vanta (general compliance), CyberSheath, PreVeil (CMMC-specific). No dominant AI-native CMMC platform yet. Traditional MSPs/consultants are incumbents but don't scale.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: CMMC contract solicitations appearing in FPDS weekly. Each new CMMC-required contract forces more DIB companies to seek compliance. Leading indicator: count of CMMC-required solicitations on SAM.gov.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires cleared cybersecurity professionals for C3PAO partnership. Talent available from Big 4 defense practices and exiting government cyber roles. Cannot be a C3PAO AND compliance consultant (conflict of interest rules).

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: CMMC is a contractual requirement. Defense contractors must comply or lose contracts. Compliance demand is insensitive to economic conditions — in a downturn, defense spending historically increases as a share of GDP.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: high — CMMC enforcement ramping NOW. First movers capture the 220K-company wave before market consolidates.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-10x vs manual compliance consulting ($15K AI-assisted vs $75-150K manual)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $1,500-$3,000/month per contractor (Level 2 compliance subscription) or $15,000-$25,000 one-time assessment prep + $500/month continuous monitoring
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $200-$500/contractor/month (AI inference + cloud infrastructure + compliance database maintenance)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $75,000-$150,000 one-time (manual consultant engagement for Level 2) + $2,000-$5,000/month ongoing monitoring
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 100-150 contractor subscriptions at $2K/month average = $200-300K MRR (achievable in 6-9 months given 220K addressable companies)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2-3x — at $15K-$25K AI-assisted compliance vs $75K-$150K manual, many small DIB firms that would have exited the defense market instead comply and stay. Market retention rather than expansion.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: 220K DIB companies x $50K average compliance spend = $11B total addressable compliance market. At 5-10x cost reduction, ~$4-6B retained in DIB as productivity gain.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Trust that AI-generated compliance documentation meets C3PAO assessment standards. Concern that automated systems miss control gaps that human assessors would catch.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Partner with authorized C3PAOs who validate AI-generated assessments. Human cybersecurity expert reviews every AI-generated POAM and SSP. AI handles 80% of documentation; human handles 20% judgment calls. Offer compliance guarantee or remediation at no cost.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Continuous compliance monitoring SaaS — companies fear losing certification after assessment, creating demand for ongoing automated monitoring ($500/month recurring)

confirmed: CMMC 2.0 is formally embedded in DFARS contracts (confirmed December 2024)
220K+ companies need certification (DoD official figure)
Manual compliance costs $75K-$150K for Level 2 (market rate confirmed)
Only 60+ C3PAOs exist creating assessment bottleneck (CyberAB registry)
15-20% DIB contraction projected from CMMC costs (analyst consensus)
likely: AI can accurately map organizational practices to NIST 800-171 controls (demonstrated by existing compliance AI tools in adjacent domains)
DoD enforcement ramps steadily through 2026-2028 (contracting officers confirmed to be adding CMMC requirements)
Small DIB contractors prefer lower-cost AI compliance over manual consultants
FY2026 NDAA AI security framework expands compliance scope further
uncertain: Speed of C3PAO capacity expansion — if assessor supply grows fast, urgency decreases
Whether DoD delays enforcement timelines under political pressure from DIB lobby
Degree to which AI-generated compliance documentation is accepted by C3PAOs without modification
unlikely: CMMC is repealed or significantly weakened (bipartisan support, threat environment escalating)
Manual compliance costs decrease substantially (labor costs rising, complexity increasing)

competitive_density.total_funding: $250M+ across CMMC/defense compliance startups (Secureframe, Vanta general compliance ~$400M+; CMMC-specific: CyberSheath, PreVeil, ATX Defense, smaller players)
moat_sources: CMMC-specific knowledge base (NIST 800-171 Rev 3 + DFARS mapping) — generic compliance tools don't cover defense specifics
C3PAO partnership network (assessors referring clients to platform creates channel lock-in)
Cleared personnel requirement for handling CUI creates talent barrier
Data flywheel — more assessments = better AI understanding of control implementation patterns
First-mover advantage in 220K-company wave (companies choose one platform and don't switch)

falsification_criteria: If DoD delays CMMC enforcement beyond 2028 (reduces urgency, extends manual compliance viability)
If C3PAO capacity grows 10x within 2 years (reduces bottleneck that drives AI adoption)
If major compliance breach linked to AI-automated CMMC prep causes regulatory backlash
If CMMC requirements are waived for small businesses (removes 73% of addressable market)
If generic compliance platforms (Vanta, Secureframe) successfully extend to CMMC-specific coverage

model_cards.one_line: AI deployment platform enabling LLM/ML models to run in IL5/IL6/TS classified environments with FedRAMP High auth
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle — DoD has $13.4B for AI but most AI tools only run in commercial cloud

demand_drivers: DoD $13.4B AI/autonomy budget requires AI tools that run in classified environments
Azure OpenAI now available at IL4/IL5/IL6 but most AI startups can't deploy to classified
AWS Bedrock achieved FedRAMP High + IL5 but models need custom deployment tooling
Defense units need LLMs for intelligence analysis, logistics, planning — all at classification levels
Only handful of platforms (Ask Sage) authorized for IL5/IL6/TS generative AI
Gap between commercial AI capability and classified deployment is the #1 bottleneck for defense AI adoption
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: The AI industry produces thousands of models and tools, but 95%+ cannot deploy to classified environments. Defense organizations need: (1) model packaging for air-gapped networks, (2) compliance documentation for ATO, (3) continuous monitoring in DDIL environments, (4) fine-tuning on classified data without exfiltration risk. Very few companies solve this.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Maven is already pushing 100% machine-generated intelligence by mid-2026. Every defense organization will need AI tools in classified environments within 2-3 years. The gap between commercial AI availability and classified deployment capability MUST close. Companies that bridge this gap have structural advantage.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: Open-source LLMs (Llama 3.2, Mistral) enable deployment to air-gapped classified networks without commercial API dependencies. Edge AI hardware (NVIDIA, Intel) enables inference at classification levels. Model quantization allows deployment on TEMPEST-certified hardware.

Great power competition demands AI advantage in intelligence, command, and operations — all classified. AUKUS Pillar II focuses on AI/quantum/cyber cooperation requiring cross-classification sharing. China's military AI advancement creates urgency for US/allied classified AI deployment.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Requires FedRAMP-authorized cloud infrastructure (AWS GovCloud, Azure Government, Oracle Government). Hardware for edge deployment available but TEMPEST certification required.

regulatory_contagion.notes: FedRAMP High / IL5 / IL6 authorization IS the product. Regulation creates the moat. ATO process takes 6-18 months for competitors to replicate.

competitive_import.notes: Very few competitors: Ask Sage (FedRAMP High/IL5/IL6/TS), Microsoft (Azure OpenAI at IL levels), AWS (Bedrock at IL5). Startup opportunity is in tooling and deployment automation, not raw infrastructure.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Every new DoD AI program creates demand for classified deployment. Track: Maven contract expansions, JADC2 software awards, DIU prototype contracts requiring classified AI.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires TS/SCI cleared engineers — hardest talent constraint in defense tech. Clearance takes 6-18 months. Talent pool: ~1.2M Americans with TS clearances, <5% are AI/ML engineers.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Classified AI is a national security imperative. Spending is insulated from economic cycles. Defense AI budgets growing regardless of civilian economy.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: very_high — first company to achieve FedRAMP High + IL5/IL6 ATO for agentic AI deployment tools captures multi-year incumbency advantage due to ATO switching costs

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 3-5x vs building classified AI deployment capability in-house (which defense organizations currently attempt and fail)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $200K-$2M/year per organization (platform license + deployment support). Enterprise contracts $5M-$50M over 3-5 years.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $30K-$200K/year per organization (classified cloud infrastructure + cleared support staff + compliance maintenance)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $1M-$10M/year (building in-house classified AI deployment capability with cleared engineers, infrastructure, and ATO process)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 10-15 organizational licenses at $500K average = $5-7.5M ARR (achievable within 18-24 months with SBIR/OTA pathway)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 5-10x — at accessible deployment costs, every defense unit that currently does manual intelligence analysis, maintenance planning, or logistics will adopt AI tools. Current suppressed demand is enormous.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: $13.4B DoD AI/autonomy budget. Classified deployment infrastructure captures 5-10% = $670M-$1.34B addressable. Add NATO allies = 2-3x multiplier.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Security paranoia around AI in classified environments. Concern about model exfiltration, data leakage, adversarial attacks on AI systems processing classified information.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Air-gapped deployment architecture with no external data flow. TEMPEST-certified hardware. Continuous security monitoring. Regular penetration testing. NIST AI Risk Management Framework compliance. The security posture IS the product differentiation.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI security monitoring for classified environments — detecting adversarial inputs, model poisoning, and data exfiltration attempts in real-time

confirmed: DoD has $13.4B dedicated AI/autonomy budget (FY2026 budget request)
Microsoft Azure OpenAI authorized at IL4/IL5/IL6 (confirmed 2025)
AWS Bedrock achieved FedRAMP High + IL5 (confirmed 2025)
Ask Sage authorized at IL5/IL6/TS for generative AI (confirmed)
Maven targeting 100% machine-generated intelligence by mid-2026 (NGA director statement)
likely: Open-source models (Llama, Mistral) can be deployed effectively in air-gapped classified networks
DoD demand for classified AI tools grows 3-5x over 2026-2030
FedRAMP authorization process for AI platforms takes 6-18 months (based on current timelines)
NATO allies adopt similar classified AI deployment requirements
uncertain: Whether TS/SCI cleared AI engineering talent supply grows fast enough (currently severe shortage)
Whether DoD consolidates on 2-3 classified AI platforms or fragments across many
Impact of potential FedRAMP reform on authorization timeline and cost
Whether defense organizations prefer government-built vs commercial classified AI platforms
unlikely: DoD AI investment decreases (bipartisan support, adversary competition)
Commercial AI tools become directly deployable in classified environments without specialized platforms (classification architecture fundamentally prevents this)

competitive_density.total_funding: $500M+ (Ask Sage, Second Front Systems, Palantir Government segment, plus hyperscaler government divisions)
moat_sources: FedRAMP High + IL5/IL6 ATO — takes 6-18 months and millions to achieve, creating regulatory moat
Cleared personnel requirement (TS/SCI) — cannot hire off the street
Classification architectural expertise — few teams understand both AI engineering and classified network requirements
ATO switching costs — once an organization's ATO references your platform, switching requires re-authorization
Government reference accounts create credibility moat (new buyers check who existing DoD customers use)

falsification_criteria: If hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google) provide turnkey classified AI deployment that eliminates need for intermediary platforms
If DoD builds a government-owned classified AI platform (like a 'classified Hugging Face')
If TS/SCI cleared AI engineering talent remains so scarce that no startup can staff adequately
If FedRAMP/ATO process is reformed to be fast enough that defense organizations build in-house
If AI model sizes shrink enough to run on existing classified desktop hardware without specialized deployment

model_cards.model_name: Counter-UAS AI Detection and Defeat Platform
model_cards.one_line: AI-powered multi-sensor counter-drone system for base defense, combining RF detection + AI classification + defeat
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + Replicator 2 counter-sUAS initiative + $7.5B C-UAS national defense allocation

demand_drivers: Counter-UAS market $2.6B in 2026, projected $19.1B by 2035 (25.8% CAGR)
DoD dedicating ~$7.5B to counter-UAS in FY2026 national defense budget
Replicator 2 specifically focused on counter-sUAS capability procurement
Ukraine demonstrated that cheap drones can destroy multi-million-dollar vehicles — every military now needs C-UAS
FEMA $250M counter-UAS grant program for FY2026 (domestic critical infrastructure)
China fielding 1M tactical UAS by 2026 — adversary drone threat is existential for forward-deployed forces
Air Force awarded $490M IDIQ to Trust Automation for C-UAS (Jan 2026)
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Current C-UAS systems are expensive ($500K-$5M per system), slow to deploy, and optimized for single-drone engagement. Mass drone swarm attacks (10-100+ simultaneous) overwhelm existing defenses. AI-powered multi-sensor fusion with autonomous classification and coordinated defeat mechanisms doesn't exist at scale.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Drone warfare is the defining weapons shift since precision-guided munitions. Every military installation, forward operating base, and critical infrastructure site needs C-UAS. The threat is proven (Ukraine, Houthis, Iran proxies). The market MUST grow from $2.6B to $19B+ because the alternative is military assets being destroyed by $500 drones.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI enables: (1) multi-sensor fusion (RF + radar + EO/IR + acoustic) for detection, (2) real-time classification of drone type/intent/threat level, (3) autonomous selection of defeat mechanism (jamming, kinetic, net capture, directed energy), (4) swarm defense coordination against mass attacks.

Every conflict since 2022 demonstrates drone effectiveness. Ukraine uses 10,000+ drones/month. Houthi drones threaten Red Sea shipping. Iran proxies use drone swarms against US bases. NATO allies all need C-UAS. This is the most validated defense technology demand signal since body armor post-Iraq.

Defense tech VC $49.1B in 2025. Counter-UAS is the most fundable defense subsector — proven battlefield demand, clear unit economics, exportable to 50+ allied nations. Fortem Technologies, DroneShield, Mach Industries all raised significant rounds.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Requires RF sensors, radar modules, computing hardware, and defeat mechanisms (jammers, interceptors). Some components ITAR-controlled. Manufacturing complexity moderate — not as hard as missiles, harder than pure software.

regulatory_contagion.notes: ITAR export controls on defeat mechanisms. FAA regulations on counter-drone operations in CONUS. However, regulation creates moat for licensed manufacturers. Export to NATO allies requires State Department approval but is strongly encouraged.

competitive_import.notes: Growing competitive field: Fortem Technologies (DroneHunter), DroneShield (AU), Anduril (Anvil), Mach Industries (Dart), L3Harris, RTX, Leonardo DRS. Market large enough for multiple winners.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Ukraine drone consumption rate is the leading indicator. Every month of Ukraine conflict = more C-UAS procurement globally. Track: Replicator 2 contract awards, FEMA C-UAS grants, international C-UAS tenders.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires RF engineers, AI/ML specialists, systems integration. Hardware manufacturing capability needed. Talent available from defense primes shedding workers and from commercial drone industry.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Drone threats don't decrease in recessions. Military C-UAS procurement is threat-driven, not budget-driven. In fact, C-UAS is being prioritized OVER traditional weapons programs.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: high — Replicator 2 procurement window open now. FEMA grants available FY2026. Early entrants get battlefield reference accounts that become de facto procurement standards.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 3-10x vs traditional C-UAS (AI software enables cheaper sensor fusion vs expensive dedicated radar systems; kinetic micro-interceptors at $1K-$10K vs $100K+ missiles)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500K-$3M per system (base defense C-UAS installation). Consumables (interceptor munitions) $1K-$10K per engagement. Annual service/maintenance $100K-$300K per installation.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $150K-$800K per system (sensors + compute + software + defeat mechanisms). AI software marginal cost near zero once developed.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $2M-$20M per system (Patriot-class systems mismatched for drone threats; even smaller CUAS like LIDS costs $2M+)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 20-30 system sales at $1.5M average = $30-45M revenue (achievable within 24-36 months given DoD, FEMA, and allied procurement)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 5-10x — at $500K per installation vs $2M+ for existing systems, every FOB, base, port, and critical infrastructure site becomes addressable. Current C-UAS deployment is <5% of sites that need it.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: Counter-UAS market $2.6B in 2026 growing to $19.1B by 2035. At 5-10x cost reduction, actual deployed base could be $30-50B as every military installation worldwide deploys C-UAS.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Trust in autonomous defeat decisions — concern about engaging friendly aircraft or civilian drones. Rules of engagement require human-in-the-loop for kinetic engagement.
fear_friction.resolution_path: AI handles detection and classification autonomously. Defeat mechanism engagement requires human authorization for kinetic (interceptors) but can be autonomous for non-kinetic (jamming, spoofing) in designated zones. This aligns with DoD autonomous weapons policy.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Drone threat intelligence subscription — monitoring adversary drone capabilities and evolving tactics, updated weekly with new classification signatures

confirmed: Drone warfare effectiveness proven across multiple theaters (Ukraine, Red Sea, Middle East)
DoD dedicating $7.5B+ to C-UAS in FY2026 (budget documents)
Replicator 2 focused on counter-sUAS procurement (SecDef announcement)
Counter-UAS market growing at 25.8% CAGR (multiple analyst firms)
Air Force $490M IDIQ for C-UAS awarded Jan 2026
likely: AI multi-sensor fusion outperforms single-sensor detection (demonstrated in testing)
Mass drone swarm attacks become standard adversary tactic within 2-3 years
NATO allies adopt C-UAS procurement at scale following US lead
FEMA C-UAS grant program continues and expands beyond FY2026
uncertain: Whether directed energy weapons (lasers) become viable for C-UAS before kinetic interceptors scale
Regulatory framework for C-UAS operations in domestic civilian environments
Whether a 'winner take most' dynamic emerges or market fragments across many vendors
Export control treatment of AI-enabled C-UAS systems
unlikely: Drone threat diminishes (drone costs decreasing, capability increasing — threat only grows)
Traditional air defense systems effectively adapt to mass drone swarms at affordable cost

competitive_density.total_funding: $2B+ across counter-UAS companies (Anduril segment, Fortem $150M+, DroneShield AU public, Mach Industries, Dedrone, many others)
moat_sources: Battlefield reference accounts — once a system is deployed and proven in combat, it becomes the de facto standard
Classification AI training data — every engagement generates data that improves detection algorithms (data flywheel)
ITAR licensing for defeat mechanisms creates export control moat
Manufacturing scale — C-UAS requires hardware production capability, not just software
Interoperability certification with existing military C2 systems (JADC2, IBCS)

falsification_criteria: If directed energy weapons reach cost-effectiveness for C-UAS before AI-kinetic systems scale (shifts competitive dynamics)
If drone swarm attacks prove less effective than anticipated (no evidence of this — opposite trend)
If defense primes (RTX, Lockheed) rapidly develop effective C-UAS that forecloses startup market
If ITAR restrictions prevent export to allied nations (reduces TAM by 60%+)
If AI classification accuracy proves insufficient in contested electromagnetic environments

model_cards.model_name: Defense AI Training Simulation Platform (Synthetic Environments)
model_cards.one_line: AI-generated synthetic training environments for military units, replacing $50K+ live exercises with $5K simulations
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + Synthetic Training Environment program fielding FY2026

demand_drivers: Military simulation/training market $13.4B growing to $21.1B by 2030
Army STE program procured FY2025, fielding to Combat Training Centers starting FY2026
AI can generate terrain, enemy forces, and scenarios in minutes vs months for manual scenario creation
Live training costs $50K-$500K+ per exercise; VR/AI simulation costs $5K-$50K for equivalent fidelity
Recruitment shortages mean fewer troops available for force-on-force exercises
Rapidly changing threat landscape (drone warfare, cyber, space) requires constant training updates
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Current military training relies on live exercises (expensive, infrequent, geographically limited) and legacy simulations (scripted, low fidelity, slow to update). AI-generated synthetic environments can create any theater, any threat, any scenario on demand. No dominant AI-native training platform exists for tactical-level units.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Military training must keep pace with rapidly evolving threats (drone swarms, cyber attacks, space denial). Live exercises cannot iterate fast enough. AI-generated synthetic environments are the only scalable solution for training against novel threats that haven't been encountered yet.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: Generative AI creates realistic terrain from satellite imagery in minutes. LLMs generate adaptive enemy AI that responds to trainee actions. AI after-action review provides personalized feedback. VR hardware costs dropping (Quest Pro $1K vs $100K+ traditional simulators).

Rapidly evolving threat landscape (Ukraine drone warfare lessons, China A2AD scenarios, cyber/space operations) requires training scenarios that don't exist in legacy simulation libraries. Only AI can generate novel scenarios fast enough.

Military recruitment shortages (Army missed FY2023 target by 15,000). Fewer troops means each soldier must be better trained. Gen Z recruits are VR-native — immersive training aligns with their learning modality.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Software-primary platform. VR hardware (Meta Quest, HTC Vive) commodity. Cloud compute for AI scenario generation available. No ITAR hardware dependencies for the training platform itself.

regulatory_contagion.notes: Must meet MIL-STD-882 safety standards for training systems. Accreditation through TENA/JLVC architecture. Not as heavy as weapons system certification but still 6-12 month accreditation process.

competitive_import.notes: Incumbents: CAE, L3Harris, SAIC (legacy simulation). Emerging: Improbable Defence, Bohemia Interactive Simulations. No dominant AI-native platform yet. Army STE prime contract held by legacy integrator.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Track: STE fielding timeline, CTC modernization budget, AI training system SBIR/BAA releases, foreign military sales of training systems.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires game engine developers (Unity/Unreal), AI/ML engineers, military domain experts. Gaming industry talent readily available. Military domain expertise from retired service members.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Military training budgets are the last to be cut in downturns — readiness is politically sacrosanct. AI training is cheaper than live training, making it MORE attractive during budget pressure.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: medium — STE fielding creates a 2-3 year window to become the AI layer on top of Army/DoD training infrastructure

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 10-100x vs live training exercises ($5K simulation vs $50K-$500K live exercise)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $50K-$500K/year per installation (unit-level subscription for battalion/brigade training). Enterprise deal $2M-$20M over 3-5 years for service-wide deployment.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $10K-$50K/year per installation (cloud compute for AI scenario generation + VR content delivery + maintenance)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $50K-$500K per live training exercise (range fees, ammunition, fuel, personnel, equipment wear). Typical battalion conducts 4-8 major exercises per year = $200K-$4M annually.
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 30-50 unit-level installations at $150K average = $4.5-7.5M ARR (achievable within 18-24 months via SBIR Phase III or OTA pathway)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 5-20x — at $5K per scenario vs $50K+ live exercise, units can train weekly instead of quarterly. Staff officers can rehearse operations before every mission. Individual soldiers can train on demand.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: $13.4B military simulation market. AI-generated synthetic training captures $2-4B of this as AI replaces scripted simulation and supplements live training.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Skepticism that VR/AI training transfers to real-world combat performance. 'Gaming mentality' concern from senior leaders who trained on live exercises.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Measure and publish training outcome data showing AI-simulated units outperform traditionally-trained units in NTC/JRTC evaluations. Partner with CTCs to run side-by-side comparisons. Gen Z soldiers embrace immersive training naturally.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI adversary simulation services — red team AI that learns from real adversary tactics and continuously evolves training scenarios

confirmed: Military simulation/training market is $13.4B and growing (multiple analyst reports)
Army STE program procured in FY2025, fielding starting FY2026 (Army budget documents)
AI can generate realistic terrain from satellite/drone data in minutes (demonstrated by multiple companies)
VR hardware costs have dropped below $1K for enterprise-grade headsets (Quest Pro)
likely: AI-generated adaptive enemy forces provide better training than scripted scenarios (limited testing shows promise)
Military training ROI improves significantly with AI simulation (cost reduction + frequency increase)
NATO allies adopt similar AI training platforms following US lead
Commercial gaming engine technology (Unreal 5, Unity) transfers effectively to military simulation
uncertain: Whether AI-simulated training transfers effectively to real-world combat performance (limited evidence)
Speed of cultural adoption by senior military leaders who prefer live training
Whether Army STE program succeeds or becomes a troubled acquisition program
Interoperability requirements with existing LVC (Live-Virtual-Constructive) architecture
unlikely: Live training budgets increase enough to eliminate cost motivation for simulation (opposite trend)
AI-generated content proves indistinguishable from scripted content in training value (AI should exceed scripted)

competitive_density.total_funding: $300M+ (Improbable Defence ~$100M, Bohemia Interactive, Hadean, plus legacy sim companies investing in AI: CAE, L3Harris)
moat_sources: AI scenario generation models trained on classified threat data (data flywheel with security clearance barrier)
Integration with existing military C2 and simulation infrastructure (TENA, JLVC, DIS protocols)
Military domain expertise — understanding of doctrine, tactics, OPFOR behavior
Accreditation/certification for training systems (6-12 month process per service branch)
After-action review data creates improving feedback loop for training effectiveness

falsification_criteria: If AI-simulated training shows no measurable improvement in real-world combat performance metrics
If Army STE program fails or is cancelled (removes primary insertion point for AI training)
If legacy simulation companies (CAE, L3Harris) successfully integrate AI into existing platforms (reduces greenfield opportunity)
If military leadership maintains strong preference for live training despite cost advantages
If security classification of training scenarios prevents commercial companies from developing relevant content

model_cards.model_name: Defense Contract Capture AI Platform (SBIR/OTA/IDIQ Navigator)
model_cards.one_line: AI platform automating defense contract discovery, proposal writing, and compliance for startups entering the DIB
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle — $49.1B defense tech VC in 2025, every startup needs to navigate federal procurement

demand_drivers: Defense tech VC jumped to $49.1B in 2025 from $27.2B in 2024 — thousands of new startups entering defense market
Federal procurement system is Byzantine — SBIR/STTR, OTAs, IDIQs, FFP, CPFF, T&M contract types each have different rules
Average federal proposal costs $50K-$150K to write and has <20% win rate
DIU, AFWERX, NavalX, Army Applications Lab use rapid OTA procurement but discovery is fragmented
SAM.gov has 500+ new defense AI opportunities per month but search/filtering is primitive
Small businesses capture 25% of DoD prime contracts ($85.2B) but waste enormous effort on non-competitive bids
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Defense tech startups have great technology but zero government contracting expertise. Traditional 'capture management' consultants charge $200-500/hr and take months. AI can monitor 100% of SAM.gov/FPDS opportunities, match company capabilities to requirements, generate compliant proposal sections, and track competitor pricing — in hours, not months.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Defense tech VC 2x'd in one year. Thousands of startups need to convert VC funding into government contracts. The procurement system is notoriously opaque and complex. AI-powered procurement navigation is structurally necessary to convert the wave of defense tech capital into actual defense capability.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: LLMs can parse FAR/DFARS regulatory text, generate compliant proposal sections, analyze historical contract award data (FPDS), and match company capabilities to solicitation requirements. AI reduces proposal writing from 4-8 weeks to 3-5 days for SBIR/OTA submissions.

DoD is explicitly trying to broaden the defense industrial base by making procurement more accessible to non-traditional vendors. DIU, AFWERX, and rapid OTA pathways are government policy to bring Silicon Valley into defense. This platform enables that policy goal.

Defense tech VC at $49.1B creates massive demand for procurement navigation. Every funded defense startup must convert capital into contracts. The $49.1B capital base is the direct demand driver for this platform.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Pure software, no hardware or specialized infrastructure dependencies.

regulatory_contagion.notes: FAR/DFARS complexity is the driver. Regulatory complexity creates the market. Any simplification of procurement rules (unlikely) would reduce need.

competitive_import.notes: Existing players: GovWin (Deltek), Govini ($100M ARR), Bloomberg Government, FedSavvy Strategies. But most focus on large primes, not startups. Startup-focused procurement AI is an emerging niche.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Track: defense tech startup incorporations, SBIR/OTA solicitation volume, DIU prototype contract awards, number of new SAM.gov registrations.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires former contracting officers and capture managers for domain expertise. This talent is available (thousands retire from DoD annually). AI/ML engineering talent standard commercial hire.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: If defense tech VC cools, new startup entry slows, reducing demand. However, existing DIB contractors also need procurement optimization. Dual market (new entrants + existing contractors) provides resilience.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: high — the wave of defense tech startups entering procurement is happening NOW. First platform to capture this cohort builds lock-in as their procurement system of record.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 10-20x vs traditional capture management consulting ($5K-$15K AI-assisted proposal vs $50K-$150K consultant-driven)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500-$2,000/month per company (SaaS subscription for opportunity monitoring + proposal assistance) or $5,000-$15,000 per proposal (pay-per-proposal model)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $50-$200/company/month (LLM inference for proposal generation + SAM.gov data pipeline + FPDS analysis)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $50K-$150K per proposal (capture management consultant for 4-8 weeks at $200-500/hr)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 200-300 company subscriptions at $1K/month = $200-300K MRR (achievable in 6-12 months targeting funded defense tech startups)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x — at $5K per proposal vs $50K, companies submit 5-10x more proposals. Many SMBs that avoided federal contracts due to proposal costs now enter the market. Increases overall proposal volume and broadens DIB participation.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: 100K+ DIB companies x $50K average annual procurement/capture cost = $5B addressable. Plus thousands of new defense tech startups entering annually. At 10x cost reduction, captures $1-2B of this as platform revenue.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Trust that AI-generated proposal content meets stringent federal requirements. Concern about competitive information leakage if company capabilities are stored in a shared platform.
fear_friction.resolution_path: All AI proposals reviewed by human contracting experts before submission. Data isolation between companies (zero cross-contamination architecture). Win rate tracking demonstrates platform effectiveness. Money-back guarantee if proposal is rejected for compliance issues.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Competitive intelligence service — AI monitoring of competitor FPDS contract awards, pricing trends, and teaming arrangements

confirmed: Defense tech VC hit $49.1B in 2025 — record level (Defense News Jan 2026)
Federal proposal writing costs $50K-$150K and has <20% win rate (industry surveys)
SAM.gov and FPDS data publicly available for AI training and analysis
Govini reached $100M ARR serving large defense primes (CNBC Oct 2025)
DIU/AFWERX/OTA pathways explicitly designed for non-traditional vendors
likely: LLMs can generate FAR/DFARS-compliant proposal sections with high accuracy (adjacent evidence from legal AI tools)
Defense tech startup creation rate continues growing through 2026-2028
AI-assisted proposals achieve win rates comparable to or better than consultant-written proposals
Small businesses increasingly willing to use AI tools for procurement
uncertain: Whether defense tech VC growth rate sustains or peaks in 2025-2026
Whether government contracting officers accept AI-written proposals or develop detection/rejection policies
Customer acquisition cost for reaching fragmented defense tech startup market
Whether large primes' procurement AI investments trickle down to compete in SMB segment
unlikely: Federal procurement becomes simple enough to not need specialized tools (trend is toward more complexity)
Defense tech startup wave collapses entirely (geopolitical drivers are structural)

competitive_density.total_funding: $50M+ across GovCon AI startups (plus Govini $100M+ and Deltek/GovWin in adjacent large-prime market)
moat_sources: FPDS historical contract data flywheel — analysis of millions of past awards improves pricing and competitor intelligence
Proposal template library trained on winning submissions creates quality advantage
Network effects — as more startups use the platform, data on teaming opportunities and subcontract matches improves
Government contracting domain expertise is arcane — barrier to entry for generic AI companies
First-mover capture of defense tech startup cohort creates system-of-record lock-in

falsification_criteria: If defense tech VC funding collapses >50% (removes primary demand driver of new entrants needing procurement help)
If government procurement is significantly simplified (DoD has tried and failed repeatedly for 50 years)
If contracting officers develop policies rejecting AI-generated proposals
If Govini or Deltek extend downmarket to serve startups/SMBs effectively
If win rates for AI-generated proposals prove significantly lower than human-written (would destroy value proposition)

model_cards.model_name: Defense Equipment Predictive Maintenance AI (Tactical Edge)
model_cards.one_line: Edge-deployed AI predicting equipment failures for military vehicles and aircraft, saving DoD $5B/yr in maintenance
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + DoD potential $5B/yr maintenance savings + Army 85%->95% uptime demonstrated

demand_drivers: AI-driven predictive maintenance estimated to save DoD $5B annually in maintenance costs
Army demonstrated uptime improvement from 85% to 95% with predictive maintenance AI
USAF PANDA system already fielded for aircraft predictive maintenance
Palantir won $85.1M Army Materiel Command contract for predictive maintenance + supply chain optimization (Oct 2025)
Defense logistics AI market $2.73B growing to $5.3B by 2030 (CAGR 18.4%)
Average military vehicle maintenance cost $20K-$100K/year; unplanned failures 3-5x more expensive than planned maintenance
Equipment readiness rates are a congressional reporting metric — political pressure to improve
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Military maintenance is overwhelmingly reactive — scheduled based on calendar/miles, not condition. 40% of maintenance spending is wasted on unnecessary scheduled work or emergency repairs that could have been predicted. Tactical edge deployment (on the vehicle/aircraft/ship) requires AI that works in disconnected, degraded, intermittent, limited (DDIL) environments without cloud connectivity.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Commercial aviation has used predictive maintenance for a decade (saving 25-30% of maintenance costs). Military lags due to classification requirements and DDIL environments. As edge AI hardware improves and open-source models enable air-gapped deployment, the commercial-to-military technology transfer is inevitable. The $5B/yr savings is too large to ignore.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: Edge AI chips (NVIDIA Jetson, Intel Movidius) enable inference on vehicles without cloud connectivity. Sensor data from vibration, temperature, oil analysis, and acoustic monitoring feeds ML models that detect failure precursors 24-72 hours before failure. TinyML models run on low-power embedded systems.

Equipment readiness is a direct combat capability metric. Near-peer adversary competition means every vehicle and aircraft must be mission-capable. Ukraine demonstrated that logistics and maintenance are decisive — vehicles that break down in combat get destroyed.

Military maintenance workforce aging and shrinking. Army maintenance MOS recruiting below target. AI augments junior maintainers to perform at senior-level diagnostic capability, partially offsetting manning shortfalls.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Requires edge computing hardware (commodity), sensors (vibration, temperature, acoustic — commodity), and integration with vehicle OBD/diagnostic systems (proprietary but accessible via SBIR/OTA).

regulatory_contagion.notes: Must meet MIL-STD for electromagnetic interference, environmental conditions (temperature, vibration, dust), and cybersecurity. Certification process adds 6-12 months but creates moat.

competitive_import.notes: Palantir ($85.1M AMC contract), Uptake (Bradley program), commercial PdM companies (Samsara, Uptake, SparkCognition) attempting military pivot. But DDIL-capable edge deployment is a differentiator most commercial firms can't deliver.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Track: Army Materiel Command AI contract awards, USAF PANDA expansion, Navy predictive maintenance pilot results, equipment readiness rate congressional reports.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires ML engineers + military maintenance domain expertise. Domain experts available from retiring military maintenance NCOs/officers and from defense primes' sustainment divisions.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: Equipment maintenance is mandatory regardless of economic conditions. Predictive maintenance SAVES money during budget pressure. Military readiness is politically non-negotiable.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: medium — market developing but large contracts (Palantir $85.1M) show serious procurement momentum. Edge AI capability is the differentiator vs cloud-only incumbents.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 3-5x — preventing one unplanned engine failure ($500K-$2M) pays for 5-10 years of predictive maintenance subscriptions per vehicle fleet

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500-$2,000/vehicle/year (edge device + AI subscription) or $1M-$10M per fleet contract (battalion/brigade vehicle fleet of 200-500 vehicles)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $100-$400/vehicle/year (edge hardware amortized + sensor maintenance + model updates)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $20K-$100K/vehicle/year current maintenance spend. Unplanned failure costs 3-5x planned. Predictive AI reduces total maintenance spend 25-30%.
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 3-5 fleet contracts at $3M average = $9-15M ARR (achievable within 24 months via OTA/SBIR Phase III pathway)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2-3x — at reduced maintenance costs, commanders keep more vehicles in the operational fleet rather than deadlining them. Fleet availability increases without procurement of new vehicles.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: $5B/yr DoD maintenance savings potential. Defense logistics AI market $2.73B. Predictive maintenance for tactical edge captures $500M-$1B of this market.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Senior maintenance NCOs distrust AI recommendations over their 20+ years of experience. Concern that AI-recommended maintenance deferrals will cause combat failures.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Position as augmentation, not replacement. AI provides early warning; humans make final maintenance decisions. Show AI detecting failures that humans missed. Gradual trust building through demonstrated accuracy over 6-12 month pilot periods.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Maintenance decision audit trail — AI-generated maintenance logs that document every prediction, recommendation, and outcome for accountability and continuous improvement

confirmed: Army achieved 85%->95% uptime with predictive maintenance AI (Army.mil)
USAF PANDA system fielded and operational for aircraft predictive maintenance
Palantir won $85.1M AMC contract for predictive maintenance (Oct 2025)
AI-driven predictive maintenance saves DoD estimated $5B/yr (Military.com)
Defense logistics AI market growing at 18.4% CAGR
likely: Edge AI hardware continues improving (more capable, lower power, more rugged)
Military extends predictive maintenance from aircraft (most advanced) to vehicles and ships
Commercial predictive maintenance technology transfers effectively to military applications
NATO allies adopt similar predictive maintenance AI for interoperability
uncertain: Whether DDIL edge deployment achieves accuracy comparable to cloud-connected systems
Speed of military maintenance culture change from reactive to predictive
Whether Palantir's $85.1M contract creates insurmountable incumbent advantage
Integration complexity with legacy military diagnostic systems and technical manuals
unlikely: Military reverts to purely scheduled/reactive maintenance (cost savings too large to ignore)
Edge AI hardware fails to meet military environmental standards (already demonstrated in commercial harsh environments)

competitive_density.total_funding: $300M+ (Palantir defense segment, Uptake, SparkCognition Government, plus smaller defense PdM startups)
moat_sources: DDIL-capable edge deployment — most competitors require cloud connectivity
Vehicle/aircraft-specific failure pattern data (data flywheel from deployed sensors)
Military environmental certification (MIL-STD compliance)
Integration with military logistics systems (GCSS-Army, ALIS/ODIN for F-35)
Maintenance NCO trust built through demonstrated accuracy (relationship moat)

falsification_criteria: If Palantir's AMC contract creates lock-in that forecloses opportunities for other vendors
If edge AI hardware cannot reliably operate in military environments (extreme temperatures, vibration, dust, EMI)
If military maintenance culture resists AI recommendations and commanders refuse to adopt
If DDIL deployment accuracy is significantly worse than cloud-connected, undermining value proposition
If defense primes bundle predictive maintenance into new vehicle contracts, foreclosing retrofit market

model_cards.model_name: Defense AI Testing, Evaluation, and Verification Platform (T&E-as-a-Service)
model_cards.one_line: Automated testing and evaluation platform for defense AI systems — the 'safety certification layer' before deployment
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle — $13.4B AI spending requires AI systems to be tested before fielding. No standard T&E framework exists.

demand_drivers: DoD spending $13.4B on AI/autonomy — every system requires test and evaluation before fielding
DoD AI Strategy (Jan 2026) mandates testing and evaluation framework for AI systems
FY2026 NDAA requires AI-specific cybersecurity and safety framework for defense contractors
No standardized defense AI T&E framework exists — each program creates ad hoc testing
Autonomous weapons systems face heightened scrutiny requiring rigorous T&E evidence
AI/ML systems have unique failure modes (adversarial attacks, distribution shift, bias) that traditional T&E doesn't cover
NIST AI Risk Management Framework provides structure but no automated implementation
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: DoD is deploying AI systems (Maven, PANDA, autonomous drones) faster than it can test them. Traditional T&E organizations (DOT&E, service test centers) lack AI-specific expertise. No standardized tool exists for: adversarial robustness testing, distribution shift detection, model drift monitoring, bias assessment, and explainability validation for defense AI. Each program currently builds custom T&E — massively duplicative.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: You cannot deploy AI systems that make lethal recommendations (targeting), manage logistics (supply chain), or provide intelligence (Maven) without rigorous testing. The DoD AI Strategy and NDAA now mandate this. Every dollar of the $13.4B AI budget requires T&E. A standardized platform is structurally necessary to avoid each of the hundreds of defense AI programs reinventing T&E from scratch.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI can test AI: automated adversarial attack generation, synthetic data creation for edge-case testing, continuous model drift monitoring, and automated red-teaming. LLMs can generate test scenarios that human testers wouldn't conceive.

Adversary AI capabilities (China, Russia) create urgency to field AI systems faster. But faster fielding without adequate T&E creates catastrophic risk. Automated T&E enables rapid-but-safe deployment — the only path that satisfies both speed and safety requirements.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Pure software platform. No hardware dependencies. Cloud or on-premise deployment.

regulatory_contagion.notes: DoD AI Strategy, NDAA FY2026, and forthcoming AI-specific CMMC framework all mandate AI T&E. Regulatory expansion IS the market driver. Every new regulation creates new testing requirements.

competitive_import.notes: Very few competitors in defense AI T&E: MITRE (FFRDC, not commercial), small teams at Johns Hopkins APL and Lincoln Lab (FFRDCs). Commercial AI testing companies (Robust Intelligence, Arthur AI) not defense-focused. Market essentially greenfield for commercial defense AI T&E platform.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Track: DoD AI T&E policy publications, NDAA AI provisions, DOT&E annual reports mentioning AI, SBIR solicitations for AI T&E, NATO AI testing standards development.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires rare combination of AI/ML engineering + defense T&E methodology expertise. Talent from FFRDCs (MITRE, APL, Lincoln Lab) and from commercial AI safety companies (Anthropic, OpenAI red team alumni).

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: AI T&E is a regulatory requirement — DoD cannot deploy AI without it. Testing demand grows proportionally with AI deployment. More AI spending = more T&E demand. Counter-cyclical within defense sector.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: high — DoD AI Strategy published Jan 2026 and NDAA AI framework mandate creates immediate demand. First mover to establish the standard T&E platform captures default procurement position.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-10x vs building custom T&E for each AI program ($200K platform subscription vs $1M-$5M custom T&E per program)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $100K-$500K/year per program (AI T&E-as-a-Service subscription per defense AI program). Enterprise license $2M-$10M for service-wide T&E platform.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $20K-$100K/year per program (compute for adversarial testing, synthetic data generation, model monitoring infrastructure)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $1M-$5M per program (custom T&E development by FFRDC, contractor, or internal team for each AI system)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 15-20 program subscriptions at $250K average = $3.75-5M ARR (achievable within 12-18 months given hundreds of active defense AI programs)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x — at $200K standardized T&E vs $1M+ custom, defense organizations will test AI systems they currently deploy without adequate evaluation. Expands from 'must test' major programs to 'should test' everything including pilot projects and prototypes.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: $13.4B DoD AI spending. T&E typically 5-15% of program costs = $670M-$2B addressable for defense AI T&E. At 5-10x cost reduction, platform captures $200-500M.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Minimal — defense organizations WANT AI testing capabilities. The friction is lack of available tools, not resistance to testing.
fear_friction.resolution_path: N/A — demand side is pulling. Supply constraint (available T&E platforms) is the bottleneck, not buyer reluctance.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: AI incident response service — when a deployed defense AI system fails or produces incorrect output, rapid forensic analysis to determine root cause and prevent recurrence

confirmed: DoD AI Strategy (Jan 2026) mandates AI testing and evaluation framework
FY2026 NDAA requires AI-specific cybersecurity/safety framework for defense contractors
DoD spending $13.4B on AI/autonomy requiring T&E (FY2026 budget)
NIST AI Risk Management Framework published (provides structure for defense T&E)
No standardized commercial defense AI T&E platform currently exists
likely: Automated AI testing (adversarial robustness, distribution shift, model drift) is more thorough than manual testing
DoD AI T&E requirements expand as more AI systems are deployed
NATO allies adopt harmonized AI T&E standards creating export market
Defense AI T&E becomes a line item in every AI program budget
uncertain: Whether DoD mandates a specific T&E standard or leaves it to individual programs
Whether FFRDCs (MITRE, APL) develop competing platforms using government funding
Speed of AI T&E methodology maturation — field is young
Whether classified AI systems can be tested on commercial platforms or require government-built tools
unlikely: DoD deploys AI systems without testing requirements (liability, congressional oversight, and public scrutiny prevent this)
Traditional software T&E methods prove adequate for AI-specific failure modes (fundamentally different testing paradigm)

competitive_density.total_funding: $50M (Robust Intelligence pivoting to government, Arthur AI government segment, smaller defense T&E startups)
moat_sources: First-mover in establishing defense AI T&E standard creates de facto framework adoption
Adversarial test case library grows with each client (data flywheel — more AI systems tested = better test coverage)
DoD ATO/FedRAMP authorization creates switching cost barrier
Integration with defense AI deployment platforms (Maven, classified AI tools) creates ecosystem lock-in
T&E methodology expertise combines AI safety research + defense domain knowledge — rare intersection

falsification_criteria: If DoD builds a government-owned AI T&E platform (possible via FFRDC tasking but historically DoD prefers commercial tools)
If commercial AI safety platforms (Anthropic, OpenAI testing tools) extend to defense without modification
If defense AI T&E requirements remain ad hoc per program (no standardization = no platform market)
If classified AI testing requirements prevent commercial platforms from accessing the highest-value programs
If AI T&E methodology proves too immature to standardize (every AI system requires bespoke testing)

model_cards.model_name: Defense Supply Chain Compliance and Visibility Platform
model_cards.one_line: AI platform providing end-to-end supply chain visibility and ITAR/EAR compliance for defense manufacturers
model_cards.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + defense reshoring imperative + CMMC supply chain requirements

demand_drivers: Defense logistics AI market $2.73B growing to $5.3B by 2030 (CAGR 18.4%)
ITAR/EAR export control compliance is mandatory for every defense manufacturer — violations carry criminal penalties
CMMC 2.0 extends cybersecurity requirements to entire supply chain, not just prime contractors
Defense supply chain has 10,000+ tier 2/3 suppliers, most using spreadsheets for compliance tracking
Reshoring imperative: Kearney Index -311 indicates massive supply chain reconfiguration underway
Single points of failure in defense supply chain identified by GAO as national security risk
Palantir $10B Army contract includes supply chain optimization as key component
structural_necessity_evidence.supply_gap: Defense supply chains are opaque below tier 1. Prime contractors have limited visibility into tier 2/3/4 suppliers. ITAR compliance tracking is manual (spreadsheets, email). CMMC 2.0 requires cybersecurity certification across the entire supply chain but no tool maps the full chain. AI can provide: supplier risk scoring, ITAR/EAR compliance automation, alternative supplier identification, and predictive supply chain disruption alerts.
structural_necessity_evidence.inevitability_argument: Every major defense acquisition has supply chain problems (F-35 1,700+ suppliers across 45 states and 10 countries). CMMC extends compliance to every link. Reshoring requires rapid supplier qualification. AI supply chain visibility is structurally necessary because human-managed spreadsheet tracking cannot scale to the complexity of modern defense supply chains.

force_alignment_detail.mechanism: AI enables: (1) automated ITAR/EAR classification of components, (2) supplier risk scoring from financial/news/compliance data, (3) alternative supplier discovery and qualification, (4) predictive disruption alerts from global supply chain signals, (5) automated CMMC compliance verification across supplier network.

Reshoring imperative (Kearney -311) means defense supply chains are being reconfigured. US-China decoupling requires finding non-Chinese sources for critical components. AUKUS/NATO interoperability requires supply chain transparency across allied nations. Every geopolitical shift creates supply chain compliance complexity.

Manufacturing-focused defense VC rose to $4.7B across 39 deals in 2025. Arsenal-1 (Anduril) and similar manufacturing investments create new supply chain nodes requiring integration and compliance tracking.

supply_chain_dependency.notes: Software platform with API integrations to supplier databases, financial data, news feeds. No hardware dependencies.

regulatory_contagion.notes: ITAR/EAR, CMMC 2.0, DFARS, Buy American Act, Berry Amendment, Specialty Metals Clause — defense supply chain regulation is the most complex compliance environment in manufacturing. Every regulation creates demand for automation.

competitive_import.notes: Existing players: Exostar (defense supply chain network), Palantir (supply chain analytics), SAP/Oracle defense modules. But no AI-native platform integrates compliance + visibility + risk in a single solution accessible to SMB suppliers.

leading_indicator_transfer.notes: Track: ITAR violation enforcement actions, CMMC supply chain requirements in contracts, GAO reports on supply chain vulnerabilities, reshoring announcements by defense primes.

resource_talent_flow.notes: Requires supply chain domain expertise + ITAR/export control knowledge + AI engineering. Supply chain talent available from commercial SCM companies. ITAR expertise from defense compliance consultants.

timing_assessment.crash_resilience_reason: ITAR compliance is legally mandatory — criminal penalties for violations. CMMC supply chain requirements are contractual requirements. Defense supply chain visibility is a congressional priority regardless of economic conditions.
timing_assessment.time_sensitivity: medium-high — CMMC supply chain requirements ramping. Reshoring creating new supplier qualification demand. Companies establishing supply chain visibility tools now will be embedded in procurement processes.

capital_assessment.cost_advantage_ratio: 5-8x vs manual ITAR compliance tracking and supply chain management ($50K platform vs $250K-$500K compliance consultants + manual tracking)

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $2,000-$10,000/month per manufacturer (supply chain visibility + compliance subscription). Enterprise: $500K-$2M/year for tier 1 defense prime with full supply chain mapping.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $300-$1,500/month per manufacturer (data feeds + AI inference + supplier database maintenance)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $250K-$500K/year for manual ITAR compliance + supply chain management (compliance staff + consultants + spreadsheet-based tracking)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 100-150 manufacturer subscriptions at $5K/month = $500-750K MRR (achievable in 9-12 months targeting tier 2/3 defense suppliers)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2-3x — at accessible compliance costs, more tier 3/4 suppliers can participate in defense supply chains. Currently many small manufacturers avoid defense work because ITAR/CMMC compliance is too expensive.
unit_economics.economic_force_tam: 100K+ DIB companies need supply chain compliance. Average $50K-$250K annual compliance spend. Total addressable: $5-25B. AI platform captures $500M-$2B at 5-8x cost reduction.

fear_friction.primary_friction: Concern about sharing proprietary supplier relationships and component data in a platform. Fear that competitors could gain supply chain intelligence.
fear_friction.resolution_path: Zero-knowledge architecture where each manufacturer's supply chain data is isolated. Aggregated anonymized risk data improves platform without exposing individual company information. SOC 2 Type II + FedRAMP authorization demonstrates data security.
fear_friction.fear_driven_demand_created: Supply chain risk intelligence subscription — early warning on supplier financial distress, geopolitical disruptions, and compliance violations affecting defense supply chains

confirmed: Defense logistics AI market $2.73B growing at 18.4% CAGR (market reports Jan 2026)
CMMC 2.0 extends cybersecurity requirements to supply chain (DFARS)
ITAR/EAR compliance is legally mandatory with criminal penalties
100K+ companies in DIB with supply chain compliance obligations
GAO has repeatedly flagged defense supply chain visibility as national security risk
Reshoring index -311 indicating active supply chain reconfiguration (Kearney)
likely: AI can accurately classify ITAR/EAR-controlled components (NLP analysis of technical specifications and USML/CCL categories)
CMMC supply chain requirements expand over 2026-2028
Defense primes increasingly require digital supply chain integration from tier 2/3 suppliers
Reshoring creates demand for rapid supplier qualification and onboarding
uncertain: Whether defense primes mandate specific supply chain platforms (could create winner-take-all dynamics)
Speed of tier 2/3 supplier digital transformation (many are small machine shops with limited IT)
Whether Exostar's existing defense supply chain network creates insurmountable network effects
Impact of potential ITAR reform on compliance complexity (if simplified, reduces urgency)
unlikely: ITAR/EAR compliance requirements are relaxed (national security environment argues for tightening)
Defense supply chains become simpler (trend is toward more complexity from reshoring, CMMC, and allied interoperability)

competitive_density.total_funding: $200M+ (Exostar established player, plus defense supply chain AI startups and commercial SCM platforms entering defense)
moat_sources: Defense-specific compliance knowledge (ITAR/EAR/CMMC/Berry Amendment/Specialty Metals) creates domain expertise barrier
Supplier network effects — more suppliers on platform = better risk data and alternative supplier matching
FedRAMP authorization for handling CUI in supply chain data
Integration with prime contractor procurement systems creates switching costs
Compliance track record — clean ITAR record becomes a selling point for onboarding new manufacturers

falsification_criteria: If ITAR reform significantly simplifies export control compliance (unlikely given geopolitical environment)
If Exostar or SAP/Oracle defense modules add AI capabilities that eliminate need for specialized platform
If defense primes build proprietary supply chain visibility tools and require suppliers to use them
If tier 2/3 defense suppliers prove resistant to adopting digital supply chain tools
If reshoring slows significantly (reduces supplier qualification demand)

models_constructed.name: CMMC Compliance Automation Platform
models_constructed.rationale: 220K mandatory customers, regulatory driver, high margins, defensible

models_constructed.name: Classified Environment AI Deployment Platform
models_constructed.rationale: $13.4B AI budget but 95% of AI tools can't deploy to classified. Extreme ATO moat.

models_constructed.name: Counter-UAS AI Detection and Defeat Platform
models_constructed.rationale: 25.8% CAGR market, proven battlefield demand, but capital-intensive hardware play

models_constructed.name: Defense AI Training Simulation Platform
models_constructed.rationale: 10-100x cost advantage, STE fielding creates insertion point, but cultural adoption uncertain

models_constructed.name: Defense Contract Capture AI Platform
models_constructed.rationale: Exploits $49.1B defense tech VC wave. Demand time-limited to startup entry surge.

models_constructed.name: Defense Equipment Predictive Maintenance AI
models_constructed.rationale: $5B/yr savings proven. Edge DDIL deployment is differentiator. Palantir incumbent risk.

models_constructed.name: Defense AI Testing & Evaluation Platform
models_constructed.rationale: Zero fear friction. Mandatory T&E + no existing standard platform = greenfield structural winner.

models_constructed.name: Defense Supply Chain Compliance Platform
models_constructed.rationale: ITAR/CMMC mandatory compliance. Reshoring creates demand. Exostar incumbent risk.

summary.key_insight: Defense AI is the highest-scoring sector in the entire model inventory. 3 of top 10 models overall are defense. The sector combines: (1) $13.4B dedicated budget growing 13%+/yr, (2) geopolitical urgency creating insensitivity to economic cycles, (3) regulatory moats (ITAR, FedRAMP, ATO, CMMC, clearances) that protect first movers, and (4) low fear friction (buyers WANT AI). The primary constraints are talent (cleared engineers) and procurement friction (government buying process), not market demand. Startups that navigate procurement and security clearance barriers face less competition and stickier customers than any civilian sector.
